out of them yes sometimes when I talk to

it's like pulling teeth did you pay
attention to the whole context did you
listen closely to the explanation for
the expression like pulling teeth so
what do you understand now does this
idiom refer to something being painful
or something being difficult something
being difficult correct let's review our
three expressions are three idioms about
teeth
if you have a sweet tooth you have a
love for sweet foods foods with lots of
sugar if you bite off more than you can
chew you take on more than you can
handle you could be taking on too much
work or you could be facing too big of a
challenge if getting someone to do
something is like pulling teeth it's
very difficult it's hard to get that
person to agree to do what you want
usually it's a matter of getting
information getting that person to
provide answers or details exercise 1
choose the correct description of the
situation 1 it's not easy to have a
conversation with Jerry he usually gives
short responses to my questions and I
get the feeling that he doesn't really
want to share anything personal with
anyone at work which is the correct
description of the situation a Jerry
doesn't have a sweet tooth or be talking
to Jerry is like pulling teeth
answer b 2 on my sister's birthday I
usually buy her something special from
the bakery these kinds of treats make
her happy on any day of the year which
description is the correct one a my
sister has a sweet tooth or be my sister
bites off more than she can chew
answer a three the detective questioned
the suspect for over an hour but he
could not get the suspect to give any
useful information which is the correct
description a the process was like
pulling teeth or be the suspect had a
sweet tooth
answer a for Adams problem is that he
can't say no he tries to meet every

trying to get everything done on time
which is the correct description a Adam
